tit.e: Kuni no miyatsuko (regional governor in ancient Japan)
tit.cmt: (government post) government postには違いないと思いますが、これだと中央官僚のようにも聞こえるので、regional governor in ancient Japan（古代日本の地域の統括者）としました。
tit.e: Kuni no miyatsuko (regional governor in ancient Japan)

sen.j: 国造（くに の みやつこ・こくぞう）は、律令制が導入される以前のヤマト王権の地方支配形態の一つである。
sen.e: Kuni no miyatsuko was a word representing a form of Yamato Kingdom's rule over regions before the ritsuryo legal code system was introduced.
Kuni no miyatsuko was a post, or an official to the post, placed to govern regions across Japan before the Ritsuryo legal code system was introduced.
sen.cmt: word representing a form of …. 国造という語というのではなく、ポストとして文を整えました。
sen.e: Kuni no miyatsuko was a post, or an official to the post, placed to govern regions across Japan before the Ritsuryo legal code system was introduced.

sen.j: 訓の「みやつこ」とは「御奴（ミヤツコ）」または「御家つ子」の意味とされる。
sen.e: It is said that the Japanese reading 'miyatsuko' came from 'Miyatsuko' meaning servants or 'Miyatsuko' meaning retainers of the monarch.
It is said that the Japanese reading 'miyatsuko' came from 'Miyatsuko' meaning servants or 'Miyatsuko' meaning retainers of the monarch.
It is said that the Japanese reading 'miyatsuko' came from 'Miyatsuko' meaning servants or 'Miyatsuko' meaning retainers of the monarch.

sen.j: ヤマト王権の行政区分の一つである国の長と言う意味で、この国がしめす範囲は、令制国が整備される前の行政区分であるためはっきりと判明していない。
sen.e: Kuni no miyatsuko means the head of Kuni, an administrative district of the Yamato Kingdom; although the borders of Kuni are not clearly known because it was an administrative district before Ryoseikoku was developed.

Kuni no miyatsuko means the head of kuni, an administrative district of the Yamato Kingdom, although the borders of each Kuni are not clearly known because the Ryoseikoku system, or provinces of Japan, was still not well developled.

Kuni no miyatsuko means the head of kuni, an administrative district of the Yamato Kingdom, although the borders of each Kuni are not clearly known because the Ryoseikoku system, or provinces of Japan, was still not well developled.

sen.j: 元来、その地域の豪族が支配していた領域がそのまま国として扱われていたと考えられている。
sen.e: It is considered that the territories originally ruled by the regional powerful clans were treated as Kuni.
It is considered that the territories that powerful regional clans had long ruled became recognized as countries (kuni) as they were.
It is considered that the territories that powerful regional clans had long ruled became recognized as countries (kuni) as they were.

sen.j: また国造の定員も1人とは限らず、一つの国に複数の国造がいる場合もあったようである。
sen.e: The prescribed number of Kuni no miyatsuko was not necessarily one; it is supposed that sometimes two or more Kuni no miyatsuko ruled one Kuni.
The prescribed number of Kuni no miyatsuko was not necessarily one; it is supposed that sometimes two or more Kuni no miyatsuko ruled one Kuni.
The prescribed number of Kuni no miyatsuko was not necessarily one; it is supposed that sometimes two or more Kuni no miyatsuko ruled one Kuni.

sen.j: ヤマト王権への忠誠度が高い県主とは違い、元々、国主（くにぬし）と言われていた有力な地方の豪族がヤマト王権に服したときに、そのまま国造に任命され、臣・連・君・公・直などの姓が贈られ、かなりの自主性の下にその地方の支配を任されていた。
sen.e: Unlike Agata no nushi who had the high loyalty to the Yamato Kingdom, each Kuni no miyatsuko was originally the regional powerful clan called Kuninushi; when the Kuninushi submitted to the Yamato Kingdom, he was appointed Kuni no miyatsuko of his Kuni and entrusted the control of the region quite independently, conferred on the family tile of Omi, Muraji, Kimi, Kimi, Atai or the like.

Unlike Agata no nushi, who were highly loyal to the Yamato Kingdom, each Kuni no miyatsuko was originally the regional powerful clan called Kuninushi (lord of the country), and was later appointed as kuni no miyatsuko of his 'country' by the Yamato Kingdom when the 'country' submitted to the Kingdom, being granted to use one of the official family titles of the Kingdom, such as Omi (臣), Muraji (連), Kimi (君), Kimi (公), or Atai (直); and thus each of the district governed by kuni no miyatsuko was autonomous accordingly.
sen.cmt: Kuninushi --> Kuninushi (a lord of the country)県主と違って、国造は元々国主だったので、統治は自主的だったという趣旨になるよう文を調整しました。
sen.e: Unlike Agata no nushi, who were highly loyal to the Yamato Kingdom, each Kuni no miyatsuko was originally the regional powerful clan called Kuninushi (lord of the country), and was later appointed as kuni no miyatsuko of his 'country' by the Yamato Kingdom when the 'country' submitted to the Kingdom, being granted to use one of the official family titles of the Kingdom, such as Omi (臣), Muraji (連), Kimi (君), Kimi (公), or Atai (直); and thus each of the district governed by kuni no miyatsuko was autonomous accordingly.

sen.j: そのため軍事権、裁判権を持つなどその職権の範囲はかなり広かった。
sen.e: For that reason, the official power of Kuni no miyatsuko was so broad that it covered military forces and jurisdiction.
For that reason, the official power of Kuni no miyatsuko was so broad that it covered military forces and jurisdiction.
For that reason, the official power of Kuni no miyatsuko was so broad that it covered military forces and jurisdiction.

sen.j: 国造には、東国の国造のように部民や屯倉の管理なども行っていたり、出雲の国造のように神祇を祀り、祭祀により領内を統治することなども行っていたり、紀国造などのように外交に従事したりしたことなどが分かる。
sen.e: It is known that Kuni no miyatsuko were involved in various affairs such that Kuni no miyatsuko in Togoku managed Bemin, clans and groups of people, and Miyake, lands directly held by the Yamato Kingdom; that Kuni no miyatsuko in Izumo conducted religious ceremonies and ruled the territory by religion; and that Kuni no miyatsuko in Ki was involved in diplomacy.

It is known that kuni no miyatsuko were involved in various affairs: the kuni no miyatsuko in Togoku took charge of managing Bemin (the people controlled by the authority through various classifications) and Miyake (lands directly held by the Yamato Kingdom); the one in Izumo conducted religious ceremonies to govern the territory by religion; and the one in Ki got involved in foreign affairs.
sen.cmt: Bemin, clans and groups of people -->Bemin (the people controlled by the authority through various classifications) としてみました。
sen.e: It is known that kuni no miyatsuko were involved in various affairs: the kuni no miyatsuko in Togoku took charge of managing Bemin (the people controlled by the authority through various classifications) and Miyake (lands directly held by the Yamato Kingdom); the one in Izumo conducted religious ceremonies to govern the territory by religion; and the one in Ki got involved in foreign affairs.

sen.j: また、筑紫の国造のように北九州を勢力下に入れ、ヤマト政権に反抗する者もいた。
sen.e: Some Kuni no miyatsuko opposed the Yamato Kingdom such that Kuni no miyatsuko in Tsukushi conquered Kitakyushu.
And there were some Kuni no miyatsuko who oppsed to the Yamato Kingdon, including the one in Tsukushi, who conquered the entire northern Kyushu.
And there were some Kuni no miyatsuko who oppsed to the Yamato Kingdon, including the one in Tsukushi, who conquered the entire northern Kyushu.

sen.j: 国造の下に県（あがた）があり、かなり整備された国県制があったとする見解もある。
sen.e: There is an opinion that the Yamato Kingdom had highly developed Kokkensei system by which Kuni ruled by Kuni no miyatsuko had subdistricts called Agata.
There is an opinion that the Yamato Kingdom had a well-organized Kokkensei system (country-province system), in which each Kuni ruled by Kuni no miyatsuko included subdistricts called Agata.
sen.cmt: highly developed --> well organized 先進的だったという意味ではないのでそうしました。
sen.e: There is an opinion that the Yamato Kingdom had a well-organized Kokkensei system (country-province system), in which each Kuni ruled by Kuni no miyatsuko included subdistricts called Agata.

sen.j: しかし、国造制の実態や中小豪族との関係で不明な点が多く、律令制以前の地方支配の実態は明確になっていない。
sen.e: The actual conditions of regional rule before introduction of the ritsuryo system is not apparent, because there are a lot of things unknown including the actual conditions of the Kuni no miyatsuko system and the relationship between Kuni no miyatsuko and the powerful clans in the capital.

The actual conditions of regional rule before introduction of the ritsuryo system is not apparent, because there are a lot of things unknown including the actual conditions of the Kuni no miyatsuko system and the relationship between Kuni no miyatsuko and the powerful clans in the capital.

The actual conditions of regional rule before introduction of the ritsuryo system is not apparent, because there are a lot of things unknown including the actual conditions of the Kuni no miyatsuko system and the relationship between Kuni no miyatsuko and the powerful clans in the capital.

sen.j: 大化の改新以降は世襲制の名誉職、主に祭祀を司るものになり、従来の国造の職務は郡司に置き換えられた。
sen.e: After the Taika reform, Kuni no miyatsuko became a hereditary honorary post, by which Kuni no miyatsuko began mostly dedicated to preside over the religious ceremonies, and the conventional duties of Kuni no miyatsuko were took over by Gunji.

After the Taika reform, the positions of Kuni no miyatsuko became honorary, succeeded by heredity, as many kuni no miyatsuko dedicated themselves to preside over religious ceremenies, and the conventional duties of Kunino no miyatsuko were took over by Gunji accordingly

After the Taika reform, the positions of Kuni no miyatsuko became honorary, succeeded by heredity, as many kuni no miyatsuko dedicated themselves to preside over religious ceremenies, and the conventional duties of Kunino no miyatsuko were took over by Gunji accordingly

sen.j: また、国造が治めていた国は整理・統合、あるいは分割されていき、律令国に置き換えられていった。
sen.e: Kuni ruled by Kuni no miyatsuko were gradually reorganized and merged or divided to be replaced by Ritsuryokoku.
Regions ruled by kuni no miyatsuko were gradually reorganized and merged, or divided to replaced by a 'country' (kuni or province) designated in the legal system (Ritsuryo) of the ancient Japan
sen.cmt: 律令国 律令制度によって設置された国としました。
sen.e: Regions ruled by kuni no miyatsuko were gradually reorganized and merged, or divided to replaced by a 'country' (kuni or province) designated in the legal system (Ritsuryo) of the ancient Japan

sen.j: 9世紀成立の全国135の国造の設置時期・任命された者らの記録「国造本紀」（「先代旧事本紀」巻10）がある。
sen.e: There is 'Kuni no miyatsuko Hongi' ('Sendai kuji hongi' Vol. 10), which is a record on the periods of establishment of 135 Kuni no miyatsuko across the country which was founded in the 9th century and the persons who were appointed Kuni no miyatsuko.

There is 'Kuni no miyatsuko Hongi' ('Sendai kuji hongi' Vol. 10), which is a record on the periods of establishment of 135 Kuni no miyatsuko across the country which was founded in the 9th century and the persons who were appointed Kuni no miyatsuko.

There is 'Kuni no miyatsuko Hongi' ('Sendai kuji hongi' Vol. 10), which is a record on the periods of establishment of 135 Kuni no miyatsuko across the country which was founded in the 9th century and the persons who were appointed Kuni no miyatsuko.

sen.j: 国造本紀考
sen.e: Kuni no miyatsuko hongi ko'
Kuni no miyatsuko hongi ko'
Kuni no miyatsuko hongi ko'

sen.j: 文久元年(1861年)の栗田寛著作の国造本紀考に、国造本紀という文献の来歴や偽書の指摘、国造各々の詳細な解説が記述されている。
sen.e: Kuni no miyatsuko hongi ko' written by Hiroshi KURITA in 1861 provides the origin of the document 'Kuni no miyatsuko', indication that it is a forged book, and detailed commentaries on the respective Kuni no miyatsuko.

Kuni no miyatsuko hongi ko' written by Hiroshi KURITA in 1861 provides the origin of the document 'Kuni no miyatsuko', indication that it is a forged book, and detailed commentaries on the respective Kuni no miyatsuko.

Kuni no miyatsuko hongi ko' written by Hiroshi KURITA in 1861 provides the origin of the document 'Kuni no miyatsuko', indication that it is a forged book, and detailed commentaries on the respective Kuni no miyatsuko.

sen.j: 国造本紀は、珍重な書物で一般に広く普及したものではないという指摘がある。
sen.e: It has been pointed out that 'Kuni no miyatsuko hongi' was a highly esteemed document and not spread widely.
It has been pointed out that 'Kuni no miyatsuko hongi' was a highly esteemed document and not spread widely.
It has been pointed out that 'Kuni no miyatsuko hongi' was a highly esteemed document and not spread widely.

sen.j: 大化の改新（7世紀後半）以降も存続した国造
sen.e: Kuni no miyatsuko that continued after the Taika reform (latter half of the 7th century)
Kuni no miyatsuko that continued after the Taika reform (latter half of the 7th century)
Kuni no miyatsuko that continued after the Taika reform (latter half of the 7th century)

sen.j: 主な新国造
sen.e: Main new Kuni no miyatsuko
Main new Kuni no miyatsuko
Main new Kuni no miyatsuko

sen.j: 出雲国造 - 出雲大社の最高神職として、現人神のように信仰を集めた。
sen.e: Izumo no Kuni no miyatsuko - The highest priest of the Izumo taisha shrine who was worshiped as a living god.
Izumo no Kuni no miyatsuko - The highest priest of the Izumo-taisha Shrine, worshiped as a living god.
Izumo no Kuni no miyatsuko - The highest priest of the Izumo-taisha Shrine, worshiped as a living god.

sen.j: 南北朝時代に千家・北島の両家に分裂したが、現在も出雲大社社家として存続。
sen.e: Izumo no Kuni no miyatsuko was divided into the Senge family and the Kitajima family during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, and both families have been survived as the hereditary priestly families.

Izumo no Kuni no miyatsuko was divided into the Senge family and the Kitajima family during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, and both families have been survived as the hereditary priestly families.

Izumo no Kuni no miyatsuko was divided into the Senge family and the Kitajima family during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, and both families have been survived as the hereditary priestly families.

sen.j: 紀伊国造 - 日前神宮・国懸神宮社家。
sen.e: Kii no Kuni no miyatsuko - The hereditary priestly families of Hinokuma Jingu and Kunikakasu Jingu.
Kii no Kuni no miyatsuko - The hereditary priestly families of Hinokuma Jingu and Kunikakasu Jingu.
Kii no Kuni no miyatsuko - The hereditary priestly families of Hinokuma Jingu and Kunikakasu Jingu.

sen.j: 平安時代前期と江戸時代中期に後嗣を欠いたことがあったが、女系相続により辛うじて家を維持した。
sen.e: During the first half of the Heian period and the middle of the Edo period, the family lost its heirs but managed to be survived by the female line.
During the first half of the Heian period and the middle of the Edo period, the family lost its heirs but managed to survive by the female line.
sen.cmt: managed to be survived --> managed to survive
sen.e: During the first half of the Heian period and the middle of the Edo period, the family lost its heirs but managed to survive by the female line.

sen.j: 現在は藤原姓。
sen.e: Now, the family takes the family name of Fujiwara.
Now, the family takes the family name of Fujiwara.
Now, the family takes the family name of Fujiwara.

sen.j: 社家として系譜を伝えた国造家
sen.e: Families of Kuni no miyatsuko which have been inherited as the priestly families
Families of kuni no miyatsuko, having been inherited as priestly families
Families of kuni no miyatsuko, having been inherited as priestly families

sen.j: 阿尺国造（安積国造） - 福島県郡山市・社家の安藤家。
sen.e: Asaka no Kuni no miyatsuko (written by 阿尺国造 and 安積国造) - The Ando family that is the priestly family in Koriyama City in Fukushima Prefecture.
Asaka no kuni no miyatsuko (written as 阿尺国造 or 安積国造) - The Ando family that is the priestly family in Koriyama City in Fukushima Prefecture.
sen.cmt: written by --> written as国造の表記○ XXX no Kuni no Miyatsuko ○ XXX no kuni no miyatsuko× XXX no Kuni no miyatsuko ではないかと思い、XXX no kuni no miyatsuko で統一しました。
sen.e: Asaka no kuni no miyatsuko (written as 阿尺国造 or 安積国造) - The Ando family that is the priestly family in Koriyama City in Fukushima Prefecture.

sen.j: 安積国造家の末裔であるとして安積姓を名乗る。
sen.e: The family claims that it is descended from Asaka no Kuni no miyatsuko and takes the family name of Asaka.
The family claims that it is descended from Asaka no Kuni no miyatsuko and takes the family name of Asaka.

sen.j: 丹波国造 - 京都府宮津市・籠神社（このじんじゃ）社家の海部家。
sen.e: Tanba no Kuni no miyatsuko - The Kaifu family that is the priestly family of the Konojinja shrine in Miyazu City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Tanba no kuni no miyatsuko - The Kaifu family that is the priestly family of the Kono-jinja Shrine in Miyazu City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 現宮司は第82代丹波国造を称する。
sen.e: The present chief priest of the shrine calls himself the 82nd Tanba no Kuni no miyatsuko.
The present chief priest of the shrine calls himself the 82nd Tanba no kuni no miyatsuko.

sen.e: Nuta no Kuni no miyatsuko - The priestly family of the Nuta-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 古代には、現在の広島県三原市の沼田（ぬた）地域を支配していた。
sen.e: In the ancient times, the family ruled the area of the present Nuta in Mihara City, Hiroshima Prefecture.

sen.j: 因幡国造 - 宇倍神社の神主であった伊福部氏は因幡国造を名乗っていたが、実際の国造は因幡氏（因幡国造氏）であり、伊福部氏はこの一族から分れた支流に当る。
sen.e: Inaba no Kuni no miyatsuko - The Ifukube clan which was the priest of the Ube-jinja Shrine took the name of Inaba no Kuni no miyatsuko; although the Inaba clan (the Inaba no Kuni no miyatsuko clan) was the real Kuni no miyatsuko and the Ifukube clan was a branch family of the Inaba clan.

Inaba no kuni no miyatsuko - The Ifukube clan, a family of the priest of the Ube-jinja Shrine, took the name of Inaba no Kuni no miyatsuko; but the Inaba clan (Inaba no kuni no miyatsuko clan) was the real kuni no miyatsuko and the Ifukube clan was a branch family of the Inaba clan.

Inaba no kuni no miyatsuko - The Ifukube clan, a family of the priest of the Ube-jinja Shrine, took the name of Inaba no Kuni no miyatsuko; but the Inaba clan (Inaba no kuni no miyatsuko clan) was the real kuni no miyatsuko and the Ifukube clan was a branch family of the Inaba clan.
